abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Completion Report
            (PCR) for the Industrial Research Development and
            Engineering Project in Spain. The overall project outcome
            was rated satisfactory. This project was the first of its
            kind both for the Bank and for Spain. It was developed in
            response to the need to modernize Spanish industry and to
            introduce new technologies that will improve the efficiency
            and competitiveness of manufacturing, promote new product
            development and create new, and technologically advanced
            industries The major lessons learned from this project are
            as follows: a) The project was on balance successful, in
            large part because the timing for technology development
            investment was appropriate to Spain's level of
            industrialization, the recent entry into the labor force of
            a large pool of technical manpower and the need to stimulate
            increased Research, Development and Engineering (R, D&E)
            in industry. This demonstrates the importance of appropriate
            timing for projects of this type. The Center for the
            Development of Industrial Technology (CDTI) has since become
            a key arm of the government in stimulating industrial
            technology development. (b) The project was also sensibly
            flexible in its organizational structure and approach.
            However, it was initially rigid on procurement and
            disbursement procedures, the procedures needed
            modifications, and this was done after an excessive amount
            of time. In such instances, the Bank should respond more
            quickly in modifying procedures than was done in this case.
            (c) The role of CDTI, like similar institutions elsewhere,
            changed gradually from an agency whose role was primarily to
            promote technological development as part of the Government,
            to one whose role became more demand driven and
            financing-oriented with increased autonomy, as indigenous
            technological capability grew, and most particularly, as it
            became clear that Spain will have to compete within
            technologically advanced Europe.
